body:
@pjain1 : Yes, You are correct. The case we encountered was for datasources which were not present, but still had legacy database entries. As such we did not encounter the NPE.

I looked through and could not find an obvious place where the rule would cause an issue if it did not have a value here and suddenly does, and it makes it more of a passive upgrade method in case old dormant systems kick back online. As such this should be reasonable. But can you please still add unit tests for checking results of what's in `tieredReplicants` to make sure it is a map if a null is passed in (instead of just checking for equality between two higher level objects)?
@drcrallen sure I can do that.
@drcrallen I've added the tests you mentioned. Please verify.
I have started work on this and will submit a PR with tests when complete
LGTM waiting for travis CI

@haoch, are you having this problem when you try to make a single self contained jar? I'm asking because in that case, I think it makes more sense to concatenate the services files rather than hard-coding fs impls in Druid code. Hard-coding the impls in Druid wouldn't help for other FS types (like S3) unless we add them all, and the strategy of adding these things in the code would tie us more closely to a particular version of hadoop.

Fwiw, what I've seen work for self contained jars in the past is using the maven shade plugin with a configuration like:

``` xml
<plugin>
  <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
  <artifactId>maven-shade-plugin</artifactId>
  <executions>
    <execution>
      <phase>package</phase>
      <goals>
        <goal>shade</goal>
      </goals>
      <configuration>
        <shadedArtifactAttached>true</shadedArtifactAttached>
        <shadedClassifierName>selfcontained</shadedClassifierName>
        <transformers>
          <transformer implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.AppendingTransformer">
            <resource>META-INF/services/org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem</resource>
          </transformer>
        </transformers>
      </configuration>
    </execution>
  </executions>
</plugin>
```

This will concatenate the listed services files together so different files from different jars don't clobber each other. There may be something equivalent for the assembly plugin.

If synchronization is the issue here, then a thread dump should show that a bunch of threads are blocking waiting on synchronization to open up.  Do we have such a thread dump?

Hrm, so yeah, actually, diving into this has made me realize that I think this is instrumented at the wrong place anyway.  It looks like we are wrapping the child QueryRunner to get metrics, which is a way to get metrics, but I think we should move that instrumentation into the DirectDruidClient.  Reasons are
1. The metrics are intended to measure the amount of time spent when talking to the child node.  Instrumenting directly in DirectDruidClient ensures the semantics of the metrics won't change.  Using this wrapping here introduces the possibility that other things are pushed into pipeline which muddy the specific semantics we are looking for
2. It would be great to have an indication of how much time was spent during network transfer apart from how much time is spent receiving the first entry.  This can only really be gotten by instrumenting the http callbacks in the DirectDruidClient

It might or might not also fix whatever performance thing is happening, but I think we should look at moving this for semantic reasons anyway.
In agreement with @cheddar 's comments I have retained the removal of the metric at this location for the time being.

Initial work:
2743da386a3f3d4649d0c47306f7f990ec7a76f3

The scope of changes is pretty minimal.  Before config.addInputPaths is called with the job, the configs job properties are inserted into the job.  The job will have been set with default configs, and overridden with any system properties prefixed by "hadoop." (which is an undocumented feature), so adding the configs from the job spec seems pretty safe.

Though these config values can be set from system properties, in the interest of not repeating oneself, it seems nice to only have to configure them in the job spec (where they will apply everywhere)
I'm in general agreement about the @cheddar's comment. :+1:  can someone merge?

A similar issue is present in IndexGeneratorJob.run()

Currently this method will attempt to add input paths to the config before adding properties from the config to the job.  This will fail in situations in which adding paths to the config depends on the properties in the config being set.  Reversing the order of these two lines should suffice.

Addressed: d46ca648f27d9d5e84d19a56b1c829978c032be9

Would a "controlled shutdown" type thing work here? Like, a way to tell the coordinator that you want to move all the segments from some particular node somewhere else, and to stop assigning new segments to that node. The end result being that the node will be running with no data and you can shut it down.
@gianm  That would work. There would also need to be a way to detect that either there are no more segments on a node, or that each segment is replicated at least X times somewhere else.

Since the general workflow of HadoopDruidIndexerConfig is to only operate on a limited set of data per method, I think it is a reasonable onus on the caller to ensure proper configuration (as per this PR), and such configuration cannot reliably be guessed if it has or has not been performed (unless we mandate configuration be done through the HadoopDruidIndexerConfig class).

After minor concerns related to comments, I'm good here.

@anwenxu @cheddar It would be nice to get documentation about using the new firehose. If we are confident that people should be using this firehose over v1, we should update the ingestion documentation where it talks about the limitations of v1.

I suggest adding a question to this faq about these messages from tranquility:
 "NoBrokersAvailableException: No hosts are available"
The have caused a lot of questions recently.
I think this is great! :+1: While I enjoyed the recursion functionality I had to waste time proving how it worked to myself and this would have avoided that.

It looks like the tact taken was to create IncrementalIndex objects in the combiner and then persist those.  I agree that this will functionally work, but I fear that it will be really difficult to manage and tune from the MR side.  There are new configurations to manage about how much memory to give the combiner, etc. that will make it difficult for someone who doesn't know MR to have this "just work".

I think we need to move the dimension names and values into the actual Key object and have each combiner work on only a single entry.
@rasahner Great point about the questions around Tranquility. I think it may make sense for @gianm to create a tutorial and FAQ around tranquility at some point, but maybe not as part of this PR

+1. Another question that pops up now and then in forums is related to realtime tasks not completing and segment handoff not working, probably worth documenting the scenarios that may lead to segment handoff not working. I am fine if that goes as a separate PR too.
Probably we can emit the rejected events to an http end point and the listener of the end point can do whatever he wants i.e log to a kafka topic or save in some other place or take some action.
@drcrallen @xvrl any more concerns?
I agree that we should have some docs about it.  Should also be in the experimental section of the docs though.
@fjy will see and fix

@fjy no particular concerns. Maybe we can remove the temporary folder in the tests to limit I/O during tests runs, they don't seem to be used other than for their paths. But I don't want to hold up the PR on this, so feel free to merge. We can clean up IO in a different PR.

Just to close this discussion, based on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1411, the overhead is typically under a millisecond for a million rows, even with highly filtered results, which we agreed with @cheddar is perfectly acceptable.
lgtm, gonna merge without CI finishing because it's docs-only.

LGTM

but, here is a caveat: if someone used something like
druid.db.tables.configTable=ABC
in their old properties file, which wouldn't have taken any effect due to the code bug. However, if they run ConvertProperties tool, that will be converted to correct property and suddenly ABC will become the config table for them instead of druid_config. This scenario is highly improbable, so I think its fine.

@xvrl @drcrallen what do you think?
